Name: Deductive Reasoning - PE
Text: First I ll need to calculate the total resolution time for each case The resolution time is from when the ticket is received to when it s closed So for each case I ll take the timestamp of the last event Close Ticket and subtract the timestamp of the first event Receive Ticket This will give me the total time each ticket was open

Name: Deductive Reasoning - PE
Text: Looking at the data Case 101 From 08 00 to 10 15 Thats 2 hours and 15 minutes Case 102 From 08 05 on March 1 to 09 15 on March 2 Thats over 25 hours Case 103 08 10 to 09 30 which is 1 hour 20 minutes Case 104 08 20 on March 1 to 08 30 on March 2 Thats about 24 hours Case 105 08 25 on March 1 to 09 30 on March 3 Thats almost 48 hours

Name: Pattern Recognition - PE
Text: So Cases 102 104 and especially 105 are taking much longer than the others Cases 101 and 103 are resolved within a couple of hours which seems normal

Name: Deductive Reasoning - PE
Text: Starting with Case 102 The flow is Receive Triage Assign to Level 1 then Escalate to Level 2 Investigate Resolve Close The escalation happens at 11 30 but the investigation doesnt start until 14 00 the same day Wait thats a 2 5 hour gap Then after investigation the ticket is resolved the next day at 09 00 which is about 19 hours later Thats a significant wait So the delay after escalation and before investigation is one issue Also the time from investigation to resolution is another long wait

Name: Deductive Reasoning - PE
Text: Case 104 Receive Triage Assign Investigate Resolve Close The investigation starts at 13 00 on March 1 but resolve is at 08 00 the next day Thats 19 hours So a long wait after investigation before resolution

Name: Deductive Reasoning - PE
Text: Case 105 This one is more complex After Receive Triage Assign Investigate then Escalate to Level 2 The escalation is at 10 00 but the next investigation is at 14 00 on March 2 which is almost two days later Then resolve and close on March 3 So theres a huge gap after escalation over 38 hours before the next activity

Name: Inductive Reasoning - PE
Text: Looking for patterns the main issues seem to be 1 Escalations leading to significant delays Cases that escalate take much longer because after escalation the next steps are delayed 2 Long waiting times between activities especially after escalation and after investigation For example in Case 102 after escalation it took 2 5 hours to start investigation and then 19 hours to resolve In Case 105 after escalation it took over a day to do anything else 3 Delays in the investigation phase itself Some cases have quicker investigations but others take longer contributing to the overall time

Name: Hypothesis Generation - PE
Text: Why might these delays be happening Maybe the Level 2 agents are overloaded and cant pick up escalated tickets quickly Or perhaps theres a communication breakdown after escalation leading to forgotten tickets Another possibility is that escalated issues are more complex requiring more time but even so the wait times seem excessive

Name: Deductive Reasoning - PE
Text: To address these bottlenecks Improve escalation processes to ensure that Level 2 agents are promptly notified and can start work without delays Add checks to monitor tickets after escalation to prevent them from being stuck in limbo Balance the workload of Level 2 agents so that they can handle escalated tickets in a timely manner Maybe provide Level 1 agents with more training so that fewer tickets need to be escalated reducing the burden on Level 2 Implement SLAs Service Level Agreements with specific timeframes for each activity especially after escalation and investigation to ensure that tickets move through the process without unnecessary delays

Name: Deductive Reasoning - PE
Text: In summary the delays are mainly due to escalations causing long waiting times and inefficient handoffs between levels Addressing these through process improvements and resource management should help reduce resolution times
